description: From Middle English remembren, from Old French remembrer (“to remember”), from Late Latin rememorari (“to remember again”), from re- + memor (“mindful”), from Proto-Indo-European *mer-, *(s)mer- (“to think about, be mindful, remember”). Cognate with Old English mimorian, mymerian (“to remember, commemorate”), Old English māmorian (“to deliberate, plan out, design”). More at mammer.

verbs.description: remember (third-person singular simple present remembers, present participle remembering, simple past and past participle remembered)

entries.meaning: To recall from one's memory; to have an image in one's memory.
examples:
Remember me? I live in your building.
Audio (US)(file)

entries.meaning: To memorize; to put something into memory.
To keep in mind, be mindful of
To not forget (to do something required)
examples: Remember to lock the door when you go out.
Please remember me to your brother.
She asks to be remembered to you all.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To put in mind; to remind (also used reflexively)
examples: But soon, remembering her how brief the whole
Of joy, which its own hours annihilate,

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To engage in the process of recalling memories.
examples: You don't have to remind him; he remembers very well.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give (a person) money as a token of appreciation of past service or friendship.
examples: My aunt remembered me in her will, leaving me several thousand pounds.

entries.meaning: (transitive) to commemorate, to have a remembrance ceremony
examples: Today we remember and honour those who have served.

verbs.description: remember (third-person singular simple present remembers, present participle remembering, simple past and past participle remembered)

examples: knit 'this scattered corn into one mutual sheaf, / these broken limbs again into one body' - in other words, how to resurrect the dismembered god, to remember Osiris. Yet the only body made whole in these expert, lowering poems is the body of this death.
